Has anyone in the legislature done the math? A property tax cap sounds delightful for the suburbs. BUT, will the legislature guarantee that they won't continue to cut education spending? If they have a tax cap and cut spending then the logical outcome is a decimation of our public schools. Other states (check out Oregon) don't want to spend on their schools and the result is disastrous. Already, New York State eliminated Regents tests for a savings of $700,000 a year. A couple of years before he retired, Bruno "gave" (of our tax dollars) a local upstate elementary school $500,000 when they needed assistance because they were in danger of closing.
I think legislators' salaries and budgets should be on the chopping block FIRST.

As we enter the post-literate age, where visual stimulation overwhelms the use of words, it will become increasingly hard to explain why speech was privileged in the First Amendment. When young people grow up in a world where expressing yourself means releasing an image of your half-naked self to a destination that is ultimately unknown ("viral"), and speech isn't differentiated from mere expression, what happens to the hard-won political liberty that free speech was meant to foster? If the framers had meant to include visual imagery and actions or gestures under the First Amendment, they could've. Speech was privileged because of its capacity for reasoned debate and the exchange of ideas. If I throw a brick through your window, my action "expresses" my outrage, but it doesn't communicate why I'm outraged, or what I think should be done to prevent further brick-throwing.

But with the concentration of power in the hands of the wealthy few, and the corporate control of the media through which speech can heard, bricks are just about all we have left.

I escaped History of Science, as did Errol, to work on Multics, as did Noel.

I got the Multics job thanks to Tom Van Vleck, whom I have known since high school. What a great teacher! Two or three nights a week my wife Alice, baby Melita, and I went over to Tom's to learn the ropes. At that point the programming staff had varied backgrounds, I don't think "Computer Science" was a major yet. Best case: EE or Math. Worst case: History or History of Science.

The question was asked earlier, "Is there a strategy for figuring out what code was written by whom?"

Sometimes there are names in the program, sometimes there are variable names created according to to idiosyncratic patterns. But another way to distinguish programs is the use of white-space. Outside of quoted strings, white-space does not affect the output of the program. In that respect it is like strings of non-coding DNA called introns.

Noel's program were special. Almost every other program in the system was indented by a program Tom wrote called IND. (Not saying Tom invented this!) IND formatted a program by indenting keywords to make the program's logic clear to the reader. Noel did not use IND, he hand-crafted the indentation according to his own system. Tom's program had the virtue that anyone could use it and get a readable result. Furthermore, it was consistent -- you knew what to expect when reading someone else's program. If you modified a program you ran IND before circulating it for review. Your code would blend in nicely,

Noel implemented and maintained one of the largest, most complex programs, the Disk DIM (Device Interface Module). Everyone knew, that program could not be IND'd. You needed to come close to Noel's style. Since Noel would be reviewing the changes, he would fix any mistake. We kidded that after Noel left we'd have a Disk DIM INDing party -- and we did.

One aspires to do as well as the master, but copying the brushstrokes, is mere forgery.

Great stuff BUT: this isn't a his-story, nor a feminist her-story: it is or should be told as a Marxist its-story.

What do I mean?

I mean that these "histories of software" focus without justification on the East Coast and the Ivy League including MIT. When in fact the SAME experiences were happening simultaneously all over the world, and far from saying, at Roosevelt University's computer center in 1970 (with its 8K IBM 1401), "hey they have email on multics, we should install CTSS to get it", we created readme files: punched card decks labeled "run this" which would print instructions to the operator.

And world wide, Russian programmers were reinventing the wheel, Chinese programmers were printing big characters synthesized out of the fixed western characters on what printers they could find, UK programmers were demonstrating that Manchester was better than Oxbridge at computation.

Our managers exhorted us not to reinvent the wheel and paid for us to go to conferences at prestige venues, and bring back magnetic tapes loaded with software. WE IGNORED THEM in many cases because at that time, it was usually harder to install software written in a different environment than it was to write it from scratch IF you were any good, and we were...you had to be to survive early computer science classes, which were utter chaos.

If the University of Chicago had email, we would say, cool, I can program that. And then to the dismay of girlfriends we would spend hours doing precisely that: reinventing the wheel.

It appears from the record that in the Soviet Union, computer managers forbid such frolics because it was the official policy of the Soviet Union not to do theoretical computer science and to follow (or steal) US practice, and this created dissidence and discontent.

But: the active element wasn't the human element. Technology had taken on a life of its own. One innovation would support another so we as early hackers lost our autonomy. As early as 1976, in his book Computer Power and Human Reason, MIT computer scientist Joseph Weizenbaum called us addicts who were being enslaved to the machine. Two years later, SUNY sociologist Phillip Kraft, in Programmers and Managers, showed the most thoughtful of us the writing on the wall: for the mastery we had over working conditions and even salary was something capitalism would eliminate.

It's an its-story in which the machine had the last laugh.

I worked with Ray Tomlinson at BBN and I'm not convinced the 1971 date in the article is correct. Obviously Ray would know better than anyone, but I have a clear memory of Ray telling me about his "hack" -- transmitting a message between BBNA and BBNB (PDP-10s that sat beside each other in our computer room, both connected to the ARPANet; BBNA was the "production" machine that the whole company used; BBNB was our test machine for operating system development; I don't remember which machine was the sender and which was the receiver; my guess would be BBNB->BBNA). He had modified the sndmsg program, the message-sending application for Tenex, the PDP-10 operating system he co-authored with Dan Murphy, to transmit message across the network by talking to the FTP server running on the target machine, if my memory serves (at that time, FTP was already in regular use for transmitting files from host to host across the ARPANet, as was Telnet, used to log in to remote hosts). I joined BBN in late 1972, so I believe Ray's work occurred in 1973, not 1971. It's certainly possible I've got this wrong, but that's my recollection.

As for inventing email, we had a messaging system on the CP/CMS system running at the MIT Lincoln Lab as early as 1968. We ran CP/CMS at Interactive Data in the late 1960s/early 1970s and sndmsg/readmail were important components in our communication (I worked in the operating system group there). Before Ray's breakthrough, messaging confined to one Tenex system was in regular use at BBN.

So while what Ray did was extremely important, his work certainly was not the first instance of electronic messaging. But those earlier messages didn't flow over networks; sender and receiver were always on the same system. By freeing us of that constraint, he established the basis for email becoming the world-wide communication method that it is today. He changed the world and for that he deserves every bit of credit and praise that has been directed at him.

This series reminds me of a parallel computing universe in Ann Arbor.  The first article mentioned the MAD (Michigan Algorithm Decoder) language I first learned on an IBM 7090 in 1961, and by 1967 a version was running under the time-sharing Michigan Terminal System (MTS) on an IBM 360/67.  I remember that IBM had the computer during third shift in those days to run their Time Sharing System (TSS).  Users were encouraged to go online in the middle of the night, and my Fortran programs found the TSS environment hospitable.  In the early 60s, the university computing center was on the ground floor of a nondescript building which appeared to be a maintenance or power facility featuring a tall smokestack.

Re: Ridiculous comments about being "born gay." -- an excellent example of how theory becomes accepted and publicized as fact, and re the roundworm, how much easier to understand the behavior of species other than ourselves -- not only becuase species like the roundworm are so much simpler, but because of all the emotional baggage that comes with the study of humans. There is abundant evidence that much of human sexuality, including gender orientation, develops post-natally; this is almost never publicized. Part of the reason is the mistaken belief that if a trait develops after birth, it is a "choice," subject to morality and possibly regarded as a moral failing; genetic explanations are more politically correct. Another part is that the mutant gene concept is simple to grasp.

In 6 years of work at a state legislature, I can say without equivocation that the most heart-wrenching testimony I ever heard was from a group of former foster children. It was not based on the fact that neither of their parents could effectively care for them or that they lacked stability in their home circumstances. It was, rather, that they had been forced to undergo various experiences of ultra-religiosity with each new set of foster parents until they finally "aged out." Although it is not for me to judge Ms. Bachman's intentions, it is a sad truth that many foster "parents" choose to enter into the foster care system not only for the money, but also for the opportunity to proselytize and impose their religious belief systems on vulnerable young minds.
I believe she knows she hasn't a significant chance of gaining the votes necessary to win the presidency. I believe she is doing this for narcissistic and financial gain, period.

I consider this a Cover Charge.  For instance, I go out to a local bar/club where bands are playing that evening. There's a door charge of $5 to enter that night.  No, I don't resent the cover charge.  In the case of bookstores, the "cover charge"isn't split with the author.  It goes to  support the independent bookstore.  Why should this be a problem?  Independent bookstores aren't selling drinks and alcohol.  They profit from book sales at the event--and then waive the cover charge with a book purchase.  In the process, like paying a cover charge to support local bands, I have supported my community bookstore, which I don't want to fail.  Special University events in my area, when they aren't free, offer student and other sorts of discounts.  This is easy to implement (senior and student IDs).  As ECA noted, expecting something for nothing under the conditions in which independent booksellers could become a thing of the past is just going to hurry along the process.  Seeing authors live and having them available to answer questions and sign book copies isn't worth $5 ?  if cheap wine and cheese is offered, would people complain less?
